ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to properly dissect lines of poetry.
Great survey course of american literature
The process for writing an academic English paper, focusing on poetry, literature, and (optional) drama. Obviously an intro course and requirement for the major, but still very useful practice.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very interesting class with diverse array of readings.
Would like to have heard more of professors analysis of readings. Loved the choices of readings though and the themes discussed. Feedback on drafts was very helpful.

Strengths: engaging professor, interesting and unconventional (within the confines of this requirement course) syllabus, mandatory time with professor in office hours. Feedback very clear and constructive, very fair grading.

Weaknesses: spent a little too long on some texts without obvious gain-- wasn't a fan of Moby Dick, which we spent around three weeks on. Obviously a seminal work in American literature, but didn't feel too enlightening.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely another student interested in American Literature or just interested in the English major.
If you are ready to work and do a lot of reading, yes.

I would recommend Professor Glaser to students looking to fulfill the major requirements. I enjoyed his office hours and he improved my writing without a doubt. Had interesting choices on his syllabus, such as recent American drama.
